maps.name: The “Map of the World” series
paintDescription: Graphic works made on old geographical maps, including educational, school maps.
Geographical paper maps are among the items of a bygone era and deserve special “commemorative” treatment. Through maps, roses “thrive”

maps.description: For me, memory is not only about the past, it is about the present and maybe even more about the future. My trajectory of visual movement can be labeled as a simple scheme: Memory, Memo, Monument. From the activation of memory through memos or forms, I move towards monuments, fossils of remembrance, tombstones of events.

waiting-zone.name: Exhibition project “Waiting area”
waiting-zone.description:
Salt barn of the XVIII century, Tarusa
Gulag History Museum, Moscow
2023
paintDescription: Зона ожидания — область пространства, в которой парашютист под куполом должен находиться до осуществления захода на посадку. Используя эту метафору в размышлении над хрупкостью и непредсказуемостью человеческой жизни, над зависимостью судьбы от потоков времени и исторических событий, хочется сравнить человека с парашютистом, который находится в драматичной и волнительной зоне ожидания, неопределенности, прежде чем выберет свою точную область приземления. Как меняется конфигурация и скорость времени в процессе ожидания? Как это влияет на восприятие человеком его пути, как душа человека зависит от ожидания? Инсталляция «Если пойдёт дождь» о привычке подставлять ведра под текущую крышу, собирание воды или слез, капающих с неба… «Дворцовая люстра» из лагерной колючей проволоки (Томская зона №4) и хрусталя отражается в старых жестяных ведрах, корытах, которые покрыты зеркалами и создают иллюзию наполненности водой. В перевёрнутом виде люстра напоминает парашют. Расположенные в боковых нефах Павильона в Саду Памяти Музея истории ГУЛАГа лёгкие синтепоновые кулисы с изображением зависших парашютистов, могут создать впечатление торжественного небесного театра. Зритель будто пробирается сквозь облачную плотность, блуждая в лабиринте смыслов и метафор.
Фото: Алексей Народицкий

Waiting area - the area of space in which the parachutist under the canopy must stay before making the landing approach. Using this metaphor to reflect on the fragility and unpredictability of human life, on the dependence of fate on the flows of time and historical events, I would like to compare man to a parachutist, who is in a dramatic and exciting zone of waiting, uncertainty, before he chooses his exact landing area. How does the configuration and speed of time change in the process of waiting? How does it affect a person's perception of his path, how does the human soul depend on waiting? Installation “If it rains” about the habit of putting buckets under a flowing roof, collecting water or tears dripping from the sky... The “Palace Chandelier” made of camp barbed wire (Tomsk penal colony No. 4) and crystal is reflected in old tin buckets and troughs, which are covered with mirrors and create the illusion of being filled with water. When turned upside down, the chandelier resembles a parachute. Located in the side aisles of the Pavilion in the Garden of Remembrance of the Museum of Gulag History, lightweight padding polyester backdrops depicting hovering parachutists can create the impression of a solemn celestial theater. The viewer feels as if he or she is wading through a cloudy density, wandering through a labyrinth of meanings and metaphors.
Photo: Alexei Naroditsky

waiting-zone.description:
“I used allegorical scenes from Tiepolo's and Ricci's frescoes, fantasy skies inhabited by deities, in my parachute drawings. The idea was to transform the canopy of the parachute into the dome of a portable sky.
 
The canopy of the parachute, as a portable sky, as a reassuring ceiling, as a painted «heaven» of an old Russian church or a plafond of a Venetian palazzo, as a blessed shade, a hupa, on the wanderings of the world, on the way to the Place, becomes a model of the cosmos enclosed in the framework of real space, which seeks to create the effect of the presence of “heaven on earth.”

In this project I wanted to get closer to recognizing the main properties of the human soul with the help of which, according to the definition of Blessed Augustine, the different moduses of time are cognized, to get closer to recognizing the Present, which is defined as the present past, present present, present future. Is there in eternity a Waiting?
Monument Object “Unsent and Unreceived Letters” are stacks of marble letters placed on stools or old trade scales
paintDescription: Ожидание письма, весточки, обратной связи одна из самых интенсивных эмоций ожидания.
Waiting for a letter, for news, for feedback is one of the most intense emotions of waiting.

horizon-colonization.name: “Horizon Colonization” series
paintDescription:
«Отпечатки пальцев» уходящей эпохи — письма, бланки, записки, формирующие пространство неизменного пейзажа стремление приблизиться к постоянно удаляющейся точке схода, точке, где соединяются горизонтальное и вертикальное направления бытия. 
 
 Морской горизонт или горизонт поля — «абсолютный» пейзаж.

The “fingerprints” of a bygone era - letters, forms, notes that form the space of an unchanging landscape, the desire to approach the ever-distant vanishing point, the point where the horizontal and vertical directions of being come together. 
 
 The horizon of the sea or the horizon of the field is the “absolute” landscape.
The horizon line as a metaphor of comprehension of the Absolute.
This eternal landscape is shaped by the marks left by someone's hand, which become a kind of sacred relics. These are memo-monuments

artworks.name: “The Vacuum Cleaners in the Landscape” series

soup-of-the-day.name: The series «Soup of the Day. Writers House»
paintDescription:
Portraits of Russian writers seem to have been taken from a school literature class. 
 
 These images are all too familiar, sometimes seeming to have little to do with real people, those very writers, they seem to live separately, in an inaccessible ether, part of the everyday landscape, part of speech, like passing and disappearing clouds. 
 
 Standing observers can watch these celestial phenomena with participation or indifference. One thing is certain, someone bearing the same name, Ivan Andreyevich, Nikolai Vasilyevich...

The monotony of the paper inadvertently emphasizes the boredom of The Basics of the Day, an uncomplicated recipe for the «soup of the day». 

 The image almost always has a grounded foreground, the people on the shore, and the ephemerality of celestial phenomena in the background.

The clouds, the smoke, are connected to who is on the ground, one might even say that this mirage of non-duality is the real foundation of any day. 
 
 The apparent chamberliness of the diary entry turns into a presentational declaration of the significance and epochality of each day, each «soup of the day».

early-works.name: “Rituals”
early-works.description:
Soviet-French video action 
 
In the summer of 1989, the French TV channel “Antenne 2” made a film about the interaction between musicians and artists, in the context of a trip along the Northern Dvina River, from Arkhangelsk to Kotlas. 
 
Two French artists and dancers, jazz trio “Three O's” and Katerina Kovaleva, in the remote and sparsely populated areas of the Russian North, made the first attempts to master the genre of Land Art.
 
Katerina Kovaleva experimented with the theme of the border, drawing the horizon line in different landscape conditions. On the river bank, on rocks, on sand, in the forest and in the city.

antarctic-diary.name: “Antarctic Diary”
antarctic-diary.description: In March 2017, I was lucky enough to visit Antarctica as a member of the Antarctic Biennale, which was inspired and organized by Alexander Ponomaryov, a remarkable Russian marine artist. On board the research vessel “Sergey Vavilov”, artists from different countries gathered together and prepared their projects specially for this art expedition. I was probably the most old-fashioned naturalist among them, representatives of contemporary art. My job was to keep an “Antarctic diary” - to sketch everything that happened around me on a daily basis.

My day began with a nature drawing - capturing the first rays of dawn in the porthole, the first minutes of a new day. It wasn't always exciting: sometimes I sketched fog or a monotonous horizon line, nothing spectacular. But in the daily repetition, in this “morning rule”, in this routine artistic gesture, I saw the need to capture the significance and uniqueness of each day.

I work in watercolor. Brush movements are minimal, as is the presence of color. You have to be restrained, there is no other way. Antarctic water, mixed with watercolor, remains on the paper, imprinting some meanings that are still unknown to me.

There is no tension here; the peace that permeates the entire space subdues it and forces you to listen to silence and intuition. Time has its own flow here - or maybe it doesn't exist at all. The thickness of Antarctic ice keeps Time untouched from the beginning of time/span>. It is well known that the study of ice cores reveals many mysteries and helps scientists to understand the genesis of the earth. I am trying to get my Antarctic ice core: I look into this eternal landscape, into its rhythmic foundations, listen to the sounds of ice breaking off and collapsing, the sighs and splashing of whales, the quacking of penguins, the barking of seals.

In the Drake Passage, an exhibition of drawings I made during our expedition was held on board the ship. We used exposition modules designed by architects Alexey Kozyr and Ilya Babak: they were based on geodetic instruments on tripods, which used to be used by Antarctic explorers.

memorial-objects.description: “As for the objects or sculptures made in stone, they are monuments-tombstones of events or concepts. The first such objects were made for my solo exhibition dedicated to snow”
paintDescription: I wanted to immortalize the most ephemeral: snow, snowball. This is how the monument to the snowman or the tombstone “Here lie the remains of a snowman”, the monument “The mysterious Russian soul” and others came into being.
The stone always has an inscription in Latin, referring the viewer to the ancient Roman tombstones, emphasizing the universality of the “idea of eternal memory”.
— Katerina Kovaleva

memorial-objects.description: Only a few simple words will I venture to say before the tomb of our Unforgettable. On it are inscribed simple and clear words: “Snegovici ossa hic jacent” - “Here lie the remains of the Snowman” But let us ask ourselves, where are the notorious remains of our Unforgettable? Are they under this majestic tomb? Not at all. They are scattered, or rather, they have spread all over the world. When they went into the earth, they became a new substance, they turned into that great element which animates and nourishes all living things. Indeed, our Unforgettable One literally “flow away from death”. But did he love life? Here we enter under the shroud of mystery, which is part of the great mystery of the universe. Unforgettable spent his entire short century in ascetic silence, pointing to eternity as a finger with his carrot. But you and I are witnesses to the fact that life itself loved him. It was she, life itself, who created him out of the dead snow element under the joyful shouts and squeals of children and the foolish exclamations of their adult epigones. Having hardened under the children's palms, from which life so generously oozes, our Unforgettable became a monument to that great metamorphosis that brings life out of death and gives us death to save life from its banal hollowing...

...To whom shall I liken our Unforgettable One? Would it be audacity to compare him to the great Osiris, torn, dead and risen, ruling over eternity and bringing life through this great metamorphosis. Not in the least. He is our northern Osiris. 
 
Therefore, we also call upon him, our Unforgettable One, like the ancient Egyptians who were adept in the mysteries of life and death:
 
«Though you went away, may you come!
 
Though you slept, may you awake!
 
Though thou art dead, thou shalt be revived!
 
Arise!...»
 
Arise with the coming of the healing snow, arise through oblivion and mortification, arise to the pure babble of life!”
paintDescription: — Алексей Юдин о проекте “SNEGOVICUS”

right-to-rest.name:
Exhibition project
 “Medical History. The Right to Rest”
right-to-rest.description:
State Museum and Exhibition Center ROSPHOTO, St. Petersburg, 2021

“This story began when I first got to the abandoned sanatorium “Gruziya” in Gagra. 

The large-scale white health palace, built according to the canons of late Stalinist Empire, sits high above the sea and is clearly visible from the road.

Once upon a time, more than 30 years ago, the sanatorium life was booming here, as evidenced by the medical records scattered in the corridors and on the grand marble staircase, from which faded pink scrolls of cardiograms with someone's frozen heart rhythm fall out. In the mid-1930s, amid industrialization, collectivization, famine, and terror, Soviet citizens gained the right to rest. The Soviet Union began to develop resorts.

paintDescription: In my project, I try to approach universal themes: sickness/rest, life/death - and especially the theme of civilization's postmortem.”
— Katerina Kovaleva

The bulk of the project consists of archival resort photographs taken on the Black Sea coast of the Caucasus between the 1930s and 1980s. They are presented both in their original form and in “processed” form, in the form of canvases and graphic sheets under the title “Current Observations”.

right-to-rest.description:
“Cardiogram of the Mountains”- a series of drawings on forms from the treatment room, on top of various tables and medical charts, collages from found spa “papers” 

An attempt through the dissection of cultural layers to discover a timeless layer of the rhythmic basis of life.
The exposition includes “Evidence” - resort household items of those years, clothes, bathing suits, souvenirs, herbarium and other personal belongings.

paintDescription: “Going beyond the limits of everyday life and history, meeting with one's own painful, mortal body, the thick shadow of the nightmare of state crimes, deportations and executions - this shimmering second plane of sanatorium paradise explains the colossal existential tension that Katerina Kovaleva's exhibition reveals in the warmth of spa artifacts. Her optics focus not on nostalgic charm, but on the ambivalent metaphysics of the world of the Soviet sanatorium, a place where one can try on life beyond life, a posthumous existence”.
— Andrei Kurilkin

right-to-rest.description:
Unique in its deeply personal nudity, in its vulnerability to the gaze of the event, Katya Kovaleva's creative position is dictated by the reverse perspective. 

The artist is in facing this fantastic reality that descends upon her, forcing her to accept herself in a ruthlessly creative revelation. Her imagery asserts the special features of Russian culture, they color it in the most actual levels, forming posthistory into a single structure as a phenomenon of artistic consciousness, as a quotient of Kazimir Malevich's “Black Square”.

In this case, Russian postmodernism acquires its own unique nature, declaring in its images, in the words of Jean-François Lyotard, “not the end of modernism, but modernism in a state of emergence, and this state is constant”
paintDescription: Large round canvases, support the eternal theme of the circle, which also appears in the objects “Ice Cream Balls” and “Billiard Balls”. There is a marble vase in the Stalin Empire style filled with marble billiard balls and a bronze “vase” with marble ice cream.

Unique in its deeply personal nudity, in its vulnerability to the gaze of the event, Katya Kovaleva's creative position is dictated by the reverse perspective. 

The artist is in facing this fantastic reality that descends upon her, forcing her to accept herself in a ruthlessly creative revelation. Her imagery asserts the special features of Russian culture, they color it in the most actual levels, forming posthistory into a single structure as a phenomenon of artistic consciousness, as a quotient of Kazimir Malevich's “Black Square”.

In this case, Russian postmodernism acquires its own unique nature, declaring in its images, in the words of Jean-François Lyotard, “not the end of modernism, but modernism in a state of emergence, and this state is constant”
— Vitaliy Patsyukov
